> I can see the value of Junit for testing functions but
> how can you, if a procedure is updating a database,
> are you going to have test functions that query the db
> to read back the results? this would seem impractical
> in general.

I bet that if you have a method that stores something into a database, 
you have another one that reads from the database... So simply use both 
methods in a test to be sure that you can read back what you have just 
saved.  It will be very helpful if your database or object model changes.

Another solution can be to use Mock objects, but I personally think that 
it is overkilling for databases.

If your database tests take too long to execute, you can just execute 
them each night, instead of every time.  Search for "Continuous 
Integration" on Sourceforge.

> 2) <b> How can you verify the execution path that a
> program is taking unless its output returned is unique
> for that path? </b>

So you mean that your program is unpredictable?  So when you do the same 
thing twice with your program, you have two different results... really 
easy to learn ;-)

More seriously, if you have a random program (let's say a roulette) it's 
always possible to change the random mechanism so that the generation of 
numbers is predictable (1, 2, 3, 4...).  Use Mock objects for that purpose.
